awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Tuning Properties of Bi-Continuous Piezoelectric Composites via Additive Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support research that will contribute new knowledge relates to the design and manufacture of next-generation flexible electronic devices. The work will advance fundamental understanding of process-structure-property relationships of a bi-continuous piezoelectric composite, an emerging flexible material with potentially high efficiency in converting mechanical energy into electrical signals. A bi-continuous piezoelectric composite is composed of a ceramic phase and a polymer phase, continuously interconnected in three dimensions (3D). Until now, bi-continuous piezoelectric composites can only be achieved in the form of an open-porosity ceramic structure impregnated by polymers, whose properties cannot be controlled accurately and reliably. By utilizing additive manufacturing methods, this research will provide new knowledge on how properties of a bi-continuous piezoelectric composite can be accurately tuned through careful control of its micro- and meso-structure via additive manufacturing. This new knowledge will enable the development of next-generation piezoelectric devices that are low cost and lightweight, with a wide range operating temperatures, high mechanical flexibility and advanced electromechanical performance. This award will also enhance the infrastructure for research and education in the states of Iowa and Mississippi through activities designed to attract students from underrepresented groups and K-12 students to STEM disciplines.

The objective of this research program is to uncover new fundamental knowledge for the design and manufacture of bi-continuous piezoelectric composites with controlled properties via additive manufacturing. The first research objective is to understand the fundamental mechanisms of porous microstructure formation in bi-continuous piezoelectric composites during additive manufacturing. To achieve this research objective, a phase-field-modeling method will be established to generate bi-continuous piezoelectric composite designs with 3D interconnected phase interfaces of desired connectivity. The second research objective is to quantify the effect of phase morphologies such as phase interfacial geometry on the piezoelectric properties of an additively manufactured bi-continuous piezoelectric composite with identified porous microstructures incorporated in the ceramic phase. To achieve this research objective, a two-scale computational model will be constructed to predict the piezoelectric properties of additively manufactured bi-continuous piezoelectric composites with predefined 3D phase interfaces. The computational model will be validated through characterizing piezoelectric properties of selected bi-continuous piezoelectric composite structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project is to understand the structure-performance relationships of bi-continuous piezocomposites created by a new additive manufacturing (AM) process of ceramics, named suspension-enclosing projection-stereolithography (SEPS) process. A bi-continuous piezocomposite is composed of a piezoelectric ceramic phase and a flexible polymer phase interconnected in a three-dimensional (3D), continuous manner. Key results of the project are summarized as follows:

1. We found that harnessing an elasto-viscoplastic ceramic suspension as feedstock can enable support-free fabrication of very complex ceramics with overhangs in the SEPS process. The overhang can be held in position during the printing when a balance is achieved between gravitational, supporting resistive force, and process-induced shear forces around the overhang. With a constant gravitational force for a given overhang, the supporting resistive force can be tailored by changing the temperature of the ceramic suspension feedstock, and process-induced shear forces can be carefully controlled through a suspension-bridge-based layer-recoating strategy.

2. Bi-continuous piezocomposites with triply periodic minimal interface (including simple cubic or SC, face-centered cubic or FCC, and body-centered cubic or BCC) exhibit mechanical flexibility under loads and feature superb hydrostatic piezoelectricity. In particular, a lower volume ratio of ceramics appears to yield a higher voltage response. Potential reasons are that a lower volume fraction of ceramics introduces a higher ratio of flexible polymer, leading to a lower relative permittivity and a lower elastic stiffness. With the same volume fraction of ceramic phase, BCC and FCC interfaces result in higher performance than SC, such as greater voltage response and higher piezoelectric constant d33.

3. The microstructures of SEPS-printed piezoceramics are significantly affected by weight ratio of ceramic particles and dopant in green parts. For example, as the weight ratio of barium titanate (BTO) increased from 70 wt% to 85 wt%, the average grain size increased from ~640 um2 to ~2300 um2. When a dopant (i.e., ZnO or ZrO2) was added, the grain growth was inhibited tremendously, and the inhibition is influenced by the type and weight concentration of the dopant due to their different thermal properties (melting point, vapor pressure, and carbothermic reaction temperature.)

4. The interfacial bonding between the ceramic phase and the infiltrated polymer phase in a bi-continuous piezocomposite can be enhanced by 92-200% (e.g., reaching 0.23-0.5 MPa) through applying a bonding agent, such as (Trimethoxy silyl) propyl methacrylate solution (TMSPM). The electromechanical properties of the resulting bi-continuous piezocomposites seem to be more significantly influenced by the width and surface area of the interface rather than the interface geometry. This effect becomes more apparent in cases of weaker interfacial bonding.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2023
Modified by: Xuan Song
por.por_txt_cntn:
The overall goal of this project is to understand the structure-performance relationships of bi-continuous piezocomposites created by a new additive manufacturing (AM) process of ceramics, named suspension-enclosing projection-stereolithography (SEPS) process.
